entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Latin silentium, from silent-, silens

def.dt: :forbearance from speech or noise :muteness often used interjectionally
:absence of sound or noise :stillness in the silence of the night
:secrecy weapons research was conducted in silence
:to compel or reduce to silence :still silenced the crowd
:to cause to cease hostile firing or criticism silence the opposition
:a secret agreement to keep silent about an occurrence, situation, or subject especially in order to promote or protect selfish interests
